articles.description: Through quiet but searing installations, artist Pritika Chowdhry reckons with violence that ripples through generations: mass displacement, rape and riots tracing back to the snaking borders that split a nation. For 15 years, she has made artworks based on the partition of British India into an independent India and Pakistan in 1947, as well as the bloody nationalist conflict that followed in East Pakistan, which cleaved off to become Bangladesh in 1971.
articles.title: 'Anti-memorials' honor Indian Partition's unseen victims, 75 years on

articles.description: The attack on Salman Rushdie, given assailant Hadi Matar’s purported Iranian sympathies, immediately took on geopolitical colours, coming as it did just days after the Biden administration’s justice department charged a member of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps of trying to orchestrate the assassination of former national security adviser John Bolton.

articles.description: Rushdie talked in the interview with Germany’s Stern magazine about the threats he sees to US democracy. He also called himself an optimist, and noted that the fatwa issued in Iran in 1989 was pronounced long ago. The interview is due to appear in the magazine on August 18, but Stern released it on Saturday, a day after the attack on Rushdie.
articles.title: Weeks ago, the writer said life now relatively normal

articles.description: in Tehran, some willing to speak to AP offered praise for an attack targeting a writer they believe tarnished the Islamic faith with his 1988 book “The Satanic Verses.” In the streets of Iran’s capital, images of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini still peer down at passers-by. “I don’t know Salman Rushdie, but I am happy to hear that he was attacked since he insulted Islam,” said Reza Amiri, 27, a deliveryman.
articles.title: Some praise the attacker, others worry of reprisal & further global isolation

articles.description: Four people were killed and nine others injured in a flash flood in southwest China on Saturday, local authorities said. The flood comes during a summer of extreme weather in China, with multiple cities including Shanghai recording their hottest days ever during a heatwave in July.

articles.description:
Said Khatib/AFP/Getty Images
    

  
The killing of militant leaders sparked clashes that, for now, have ended in a shaky ceasefire.
 Battles between the Israeli military and the militant group Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) killed 49 Palestinians in the last week in Gaza, the territory where Palestinians live under often brutal conditions and repeated outbreaks of deadly violence.
Israeli forces launched a preemptive strike against PIJ targets on August 5, Reuters reported, after one of the group’s leaders Bassam al-Saadi was arrested in the Occupied West Bank. Israel claims to have hit a number of PIJ targets. However, several civilians, including 17 children, were killed in the clashes, both by Israeli weapons and possibly by errant PIJ rockets intended for Israeli targets. A ceasefir…
articles.title: After the latest clash with Israel, Gazans’ struggle continues

articles.description:
A vial of the oral polio vaccine. | Ezra Acayan/Getty Images
    

  
How a polio case in New York — and genetic evidence of under-the-radar spread — affects US risk and global eradication efforts.
 For the first time in almost a decade, a case of polio was confirmed in the United States. Health officials in New York’s Rockland County discovered the case last month in an unvaccinated 20-year-old, decades after polio was eliminated from the US in 1979. On August 12, New York City health authorities reported that they had detected the polio virus in the local wastewater system, indicating that the virus was likely circulating under the radar in the city.
With the country and public health system already struggling under the weight of Covid-19 and monkeypox, this news comes as an unpleasant s…
articles.title: New York’s polio crisis, explained

articles.description:
Washington has been “playing a game” with the rest of the country for the past 20 years and Americans have “just about had enough”, Curtin University Political Analyst Joe Siracusa says.

He said he thinks the Republicans have been “renewed” after the FBI raid on former US president Donald Trump’s Florida home. 

“This thing backfired very terribly because the Democrats counted on the American people being asleep,” he told Sky News Australia. 

“As soon as you get past the beltway, Americans are a lot smarter than Washington.”
articles.title: Democrats counted on Americans being ‘asleep’

articles.description:
Curtin University Political Analyst Joe Siracusa says the American people “aren’t stupid” and can see the FBI raid on former US president Donald Trump as a “political hack job”. 

He said he thinks the FBI will need to “lift their game”. 

“The FBI has never played fair and the Attorney-General thinks the American people are stupid and the FBI thinks the American people are blind,” he told Sky News Australia. 

“They can see what’s happening here – I think the credibility has been shot.”
articles.title: ‘Political hack job’: FBI credibility has been ‘shot’

articles.description:
Afghanistan refugee Khalid Amiri says there is “no future” in Afghanistan under the Taliban as he pointed to how “the rest of the world is just watching in silence”.  

Mr Amiri said Afghanistan felt “betrayed” and “abandoned” when western forces left the nation.  

“The international community spent trillions of dollars in Afghanistan,” he told Sky News Australia.  

“All the dreams, and all our lives that we had worked for, we had to leave behind.”
articles.title: Afghanistan has ‘no future’ under Taliban with world ‘just watching in silence’

articles.description:
Afghanistan refugee Khalid Amiri says Afghanistan is becoming a “breeding ground” for global terrorism as he discussed the impact of the Taliban taking over the nation.  

Mr Amiri said many young people are seeking to leave Afghanistan.  

“Things are getting worse day by day … the rest of the world is just watching in silence,” he told Sky News Australia.  

“Today my country is becoming a breeding ground for global terrorism.”
articles.title: Afghanistan becoming ‘breeding ground’ for global terrorism

articles.description: A man died early Sunday near the US Capitol building after driving his car into a barricade and firing shots into the air.

articles.description:

He said there is a sense of shared mission around the strategic situation in the world and the importance of asserting a global rules-based order. 

“I think we’re seeing a real rapport being established between Prime Minister Albanese and President Biden,” he told Sky News Australia.

articles.description:

He said there are fears of a future blockade of the Taiwan Strait by China. 

“There were few signs from the ambassador that there would be a reversal anytime soon in terms of trade bans on Australian beef or wine,” Mr Clennell said. 

“It seems the Chinese government wants to hold that over Australia as if to say there are further trade sanctions that can be put in place.”
articles.title: China wants ‘political compliance’ in return for ‘economic reliance’

articles.author: noreply@blogger.com (Newsrust)
articles.description:
The evening, punctuated by the local cover band, the Fly Bettys, ended with a final fireworks display accompanied by “God Bless the USA”.
The hope of SK, Ford, many energy policymakers and pragmatic environmentalists is that most Georgians stalking for holiday fireworks in years to come will instead be hanging from F-150 sets. Lightnings.
Even with logistics and production volume straightened out, the lingering question for Jackson County residents and Americans alike is whether batteries made on the road in SK will power vehicles ultimately as accessible as Ford’s Model T.  Henry Ford called it a vehicle “for the great multitude,” and it fueled America’s original automobile revolution.
As usual, silver bullets are rare.  And like most major challenges, it helps if a solution is to create something cool.
Maddison Dean, a Jackson County native, was hired earlier this year by SK for a community relations role.  In April, she gave a presentation on the company to over a hundred juniors and seniors at Commerce High School, her alma mater.  In the auditorium, she provided insight into electric vehicles, the rapidly changing future of automakers, and how SK operations work.
“I told them, feel free to interrupt me anytime, just raise your hand,” she said.  At first, she didn’t have many takers.  “You know, especially talking to high school kids, they’re just sort of transparent, they’re like, ‘Yeah, whatever, that’s an excuse for us to be out of class, but we don’t lend it don’t pay attention.  “”

Source Link
articles.title: Can the F-150 Lightning make everyone want a truck that plugs in?

As boring as that makes me, I liked knowing about baby gear.  My wife liked that I knew about baby equipment.  And I found, to my surprise, that learning about baby equipment forced me to learn more about babies themselves – what they like, what they don’t like, to how old they grow and come out of certain behaviors.  As my due date approached, I felt more prepared and less unhappy than many other future dads I met in our birthing classes, many of whom had outsourced equipment decisions to their wives.
And when my wife finally gave birth three weeks early, I was ready.  I drove her to the hospital with confidence, full bags in tow, not once worrying about whether the car seat was properly installed.
Since the birth of our son, I have found that my interest in his equipment has made me a be…
articles.title: I was skeptical of baby gear.  Then I became a dad.

But this summer, some of them encountered their most threatening adversary yet: multi-family townhouses.

articles.description:
It was a long-term gamble on liquid natural gas, but it paid off and turned the United States into a major exporter of fossil fuels.
Journalist Jake Bittle delves into the career of Charif Souki, the Lebanese-American entrepreneur whose appetite for risk changed the course of America’s energy sector.
The article describes how Mr. Souki went from restaurant owner in Los Angeles to co-founder and CEO of Cheniere Energy, an oil and gas company specializing in liquefied natural gas, and provides insight into his process of reflection: “According to Souki,” writes Mr. Bittle, “the need to provide energy to the world in the short term outweighs the long-term demand to act on carbon emissions”.


At a time of acute climate anxiety, Mr. Souki’s rationale might seem outdated, even brazen.  The world may be facing energy and climate crises, Mr Souki told The New York Times, “but one is going to happen this month, and the other is 40 years from now.”


“If you tell someone, ‘You’re going to run out of power this month,’ and then you tell the same person about what’s going to happen 40 years from now,” he said, “they say, ‘What do you care about in 40 years?’  »



Additional production for The Sunday Read was contributed by Emma Kehlbeck, Parin Behrooz, Anna Diamond, Sarah Diamond, Jack D’Isidoro, Elena Hecht, Desiree Ibekwe, Tanya Pérez, Marion Lozano, Naomi Noury, Krish Seenivasan, Corey Schreppel, Margaret Willison, Kate Winslett and Tiana Young.  Special thanks to Mike Benoist, Sam Dolnick, Laura Kim, Julia Simon, Lisa Tobin, Blake Wilson and Ryan Wegner.

articles.author: noreply@blogger.com (Newsrust)
articles.description:
When the pandemic closings hit the real estate sector, showings were halted, homes were taken off the market and municipal offices that process closing documents were closed.  As a result, in March 2020, almost 18% of purchase contracts in the United States were canceled – although it took only a few months to return to normal levels.
But in 2022, the frequency of canceled transactions started to rise again, reaching almost 15% in June – the highest rate since the peak of the pandemic, according to a recent report by red finwhich represents approximately 60,000 failed home sales across the country.
The likely culprit: rising mortgage interest rates.  The journey between the accepted offer and the closing day can take up to two months or more, and interest rates sometimes change in the meantime.  Buyers can lock in rates for certain periods, but not all do, and even a small increase can stretch monthly payments out of reach and kill a deal.  And the rate increases this year have been substantial.  Consider, for example, that the average rate for a 30-year fixed rate mortgage rose from 3.79% in January to 5.3% in July.  This change would increase a monthly payment approximately $90 for every $100,000 borrowed.


The places with the highest percentage of deals failed in June – including many in the south and southwest – are among the most popular with buyers.  In Las Vegas, just over 27% of trades failed in June, the highest rate of any market, according to Redfin.  Preferred Florida destinations followed, including Lakeland, Florida at just under 27% and Cape Coral, Florida at just under 26%.


This week’s chart shows the US metropolitan markets where the highest share of trades failed in June.

Source Link
articles.title: Other real estate offers fail

Send questions about office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com.  Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous.  Letters can be changed.
Climb the professional ladder

I’m a librarian in my late twenties, and due to a wave of retirements, I’ve risen through the ranks very quickly.  My supervisors like me and I recently applied and was offered a job that puts me in charge of my own library.  It’s just another person and myself working there.  The other librarian has been in the business almost as long as I’ve been alive, and I know she applied for the job.

When the summer sun is blazing, the mere idea of ​​turning on the oven – even for the most wonderful dish – is revolting.  Sure, you might have air conditioning, but why heat the kitchen if it’s not necessary?  (You came inside to escape the stickiness and sweat!) You could cleverly put together a salad or put together a meal without cooking – and we have so many beautiful ones here and here – but ultimately, you’re going to want a hot meal.  Enter the slow cooker.
The recipes below are the simplest type of slow cooker recipe, the fix and forget type.  There’s no pre-searing or sautéing, and very little prep.  Just throw the ingredients in the slow cooker and let it simmer while you head to the beach or to work, or just curl up with a good book in front of the air conditioner.  A few hours…

Polio epidemics caused regular panics decades ago, until a vaccine was developed and the disease was largely eradicated.  Then on Friday, New York City health officials announced they had found the virus in sewage samples, suggesting polio was likely circulating in the city again. 
Parents of young children have wondered —  perhaps for the first time in their lives and collectively for the first time in generations — how worried they should be about polio.
Anabela Borges, a designer who lives in Brooklyn’s Crown Heights neighborhood, said she has friends whose children are likely unvaccinated.  After Friday’s announcement, she said she planned to “raise awareness among her friends.”


Ms Borges said she hoped her 7-month-old daughter Ava, who is old enough to have had three of the four inj…
articles.title: Polio has been detected in New York's sewage, officials say

articles.description:
Sue Bird glanced up as she grabbed the exit pass.  Her Seattle Storm teammate Natasha Howard had preceded her as a wide receiver, as she usually did whenever Bird was leading the offense in transition.  Howard realized it was open under the basket and stiffened.  Bird, she knew, would find her as always.  She just didn’t know how.
Bird slipped into the lane, drawing in a defender.  Then, without looking, she whipped the ball above his head and in Howard’s waiting palms.
“My hands were always ready for Sue when she passed the ball to me,” said Howard, now with the Liberty.  She added, “It’s just there, it’s like, ‘Wow, OK, Sue. You’ve got eyes in the back of your head.'”


Bird counts the pass among his favorite assists during his 19 seasons with the Storm.  She has plenty of assists to cho…
articles.title: Sue Bird became the legend she needed: 'There was no real way'

Dozens of retired black NFL players will now be eligible for payouts worth hundreds of thousands of dollars from the league’s billion-dollar concussion settlement, reversing previous rulings made due to testing cognitive tests that used race-based measures to determine whether players had dementia.
The ruling, included in a status report filed by the settlement administrator that was entered into court on Thursday, came two years after two former players sued the league ending the use of race as a criterion for judging player claims, a process known as “race-norming”.
The settlement administrator discovered that 646 players who had been tested for dementia but were not eligible for cash payouts could have their tests automatically reassessed without using race as a criterion.
